item.title: Star Wars force awakens with standing ovation for Harrison Ford at Comic-Con
item.trailText: The entire stadium-sized convention hall broke the gathering’s strict no-standing rule in unison to greet the recently injured actor
item.standFirst: The entire stadium-sized convention hall broke the gathering’s strict no-standing rule in unison to greet the recently injured actor
item.body:
Fans screamed for Harrison Ford at the Star Wars: The Force Awakens Comic-Con panel in San Diego on Friday evening, but the scene in the crowd was bedlam after director JJ Abrams asked the audience, “Who wants to go see a live Star Wars concert right now?

Related: Game of Thrones cast tell Comic-Con crowd only one actor has read the books

“We only have room for all of you”, he told the 7,000-fan-strong room. “The City of San Diego for some reason agreed to this.”

The panel itself was one of the most highly anticipated at the convention, with queues standing for days to be let in. The panelists accordingly milked the crowd’s expectations for all they were worth. “Is Harrison OK?” Hardwick asked before he brought out the recently injured actor. “Well, why don’t we see for ourselves?” Comic-Con gave the actor a rare standing ovation as the entire stadium-sized convention hall broke the gathering’s strict no-standing rule in unison.

The legendarily taciturn Ford, when asked how he was, simply said, “I’m fine”, and then, perhaps sensing that was not enough, thanked Hardwick for asking. But he became more voluble on the subject of returning to the film. Had he thought about what had happened to Han after Return of the Jedi?

“No, because I never thought that it would come back to bless me rather than haunt me,” Ford said. “I was very gratified when I read the [new] script. I read something that I thought was really remarkable, really well-written, with some very intriguing developments and I was very happy to be a part of the story.”

Hardwick asked Carrie Fisher what it had been like to return to the franchise, about which she’s been ambivalent in the past. “It was like a flashback, kind of,” Fisher said. “I thought, ‘They were right about the acid flashbacks’. I didn’t think that it was going to happen again. I had to check and see if it was just me. It was a little bit like before,” she said of returning to the set with Ford, Hamill, and Peter Mayhew, “only we looked melted this time. But in a good way – kind of Force-melted.”

Mark Hamill said promotion had changed radically since the first film. “We only had photographs,” he recalled. There was no footage. We had R2D2 as a prop and we had C3PO, but we didn’t have Anthony Daniels inside it. With only 25 photographs, it wasn’t very easy to describe what it was.”

Veteran Star Wars writer Lawrence Kasdan, who wrote the script, was in attendance alongside the rest of the prinicpal cast. Gwendoline Christie, who plays villain Phasma, barely had an hour between the Game of Thrones panel and her appearance for Star Wars, where her character is also tall, armored and menacing.

“I’ve found it exciting, not only that there was a female stormtrooper, but [for] the opportunity to explore a female character that is totally not about the way she looks in flesh,” Christie said. “That armor is exterior and it’s more about the outside feeding in, and I was very excited that inside that armor was a woman.”

Domhnall Gleeson, who plays villain General Hux, began answering a question about his character with, “He was on Starkiller Base, which … whoops. Can I talk about that?” Kasdan sighed and gave his blessing: “The base he’s on, in honor of the original last name of Luke Skywalker, is Starkiller Base, spoiled by Domnhall Gleeson,” he said with a laugh.

Related: Rick and Morty at Comic Con: Adult Swim cult favorite is back and in-joking

Another guest at the panel was less conventional: Baba Joe, a donkey-sized, automated alien created by visual effects professional Neil Scanlan, which lumbered back and forth across the stage and interacted with the human moviemakers with the help of a five-person crew of pilots (presumably all offstage).

There was no new footage from the film, just a behind-the-scenes reel (which was warmly received) emphasizing the non-computerized nature of many of the movie’s special effects and locations.

The shoot’s emphasis on practical effects was not always easy on the actors. “I’d just like to thank JJ Abrams for filming in Abu Dhabi, in the desert, and putting me in a Stormtrooper uniform”, said actor John Boyega, who plays Finn in the film.

Of course, not everything was ultra-realistic, as Oscar Isaac, who plays Poe in the film, had explained to him by Ford. “I wanted to talk to Harrison about piloting, and are there any special things that I should do and how do you work with the controls.

“And he said, ‘It’s fake. And also it’s in space’.”

The movie, said Abrams, is being tinkered with, which he said was a privilege. “We’re editing”, he told the audience. “We have a cut of the movie. We’re in this extraordinary moment where we’re doing fine-tuning. I say extraordinary because we’re in a moment where there are release dates before there are scripts, and Disney has given us the time to make the movie what it wants to be.”

I’m not in charge of casting for the next two films, but if I was, I would make all the characters Asian.

JJ Abrams

Abrams and Kathleen Kennedy fielded a question about diversity from a young woman who pointed out that there were no Asian characters in the film. “I’m not in charge of casting for the next two films, but if I was, I would make all the characters Asian,” Abrams joked. He and Kennedy said more seriously that they wanted a diverse cast for the Star Wars films as they continued.

“We didn’t write the character of Finn to be any color”, Abrams said. “We didn’t write the character of Rey to be any color. We want our film to look the way the world looks.”

When the panel closed, it was up to moderator Chris Hardwick to shepherd the fans to the embarcadero behind the convention center – not an easy task, and one that took more than an hour. “You are going to follow these stormtroopers in an orderly fashion,” said moderator Chris Hardwick. “There is room for everyone. No murdering allowed.”

“I feel sorry for Kevin Smith, who has the next panel,” Hardwick said reflectively.

There was reason for some pity: Comic-Con’s vast Hall H fills up early and stays full, because the convention does not empty it between panels. “I heard from [my sister] that one person can hold five spots at a time after this lineup, because we had one person holding forty spots, which is ridiculous,” said Tyler Leivo, who attended the panel with his sister Amber after having waited for the panel since noon the previous day (even so, the pair were nowhere near the front of line).

The couple happily joined the line for the concert.

cards.rawTitle: Rock’n’roll America review – the gospel truth about a music revolution

item.title: Rock’n’roll America review – the gospel truth about a music revolution
item.trailText: It wasn’t that long ago that Elvis Presley was denounced as the devil’s disciple. The way the first rockers tell it, though, it was more about impressing girls…
item.standFirst: It wasn’t that long ago that Elvis Presley was denounced as the devil’s disciple. The way the first rockers tell it, though, it was more about impressing girls…
item.body:
You kinda assume that they’ve just been printing the legend since the day he died. But watch the footage of radio presenters smashing records on their turntables and promising not to play any more of the devil’s music, or of severe women in severer hats saying things like “I watched him gyrate his legs and swivel his hips and our parent-teachers’ group feels he should not be on TV” and you goggle and you boggle and you realise that there was a time, there genuinely was a time when Elvis Presley was the greatest, filthiest threat to innocence, to society that there had ever been.

Almost more implausible, when you watch the likes of BBC4’s three-part documentary Rock’n’Roll America, is the fact that it happened well within living memory. There’s his drummer and his guitarist. There’s Wanda Jackson, who toured with Presley early in her career. Still hale, hearty and full of stories about the turbocharged years of undreamed-of fame, courtesy of that lividly beautiful, hip-swivelling man channelling Memphis gospel music and turning everything he sang into gold.

Pat Boone (who must have some terrible be-cardiganned portrait in the attic because he looks 40) gave us his account of reworking Fats Domino’s Ain’t That a Shame. He was majoring in English at Columbia and changed it to Isn’t That a Shame. His producer persuaded him to change it back. The radio stations began playing the original as a novelty item. The teenagers bought it in droves.

Jerry Lee Lewis – perhaps slightly less hale, but still almost dangerously hearty – gave us his account of setting fire to Chuck Berry’s piano on stage when they were touring together. The former bible-college boy once asked Elvis if he thought they’d go to hell for inventing rock’n’roll. “Jerry Lee, don’t you ever say that to me again,” came the reply.

Don Everly and a couple of Buddy Holly’s Crickets contributed too. Tales of demos being made and released straight off as number one singles, of eternal classics springing forth at late-night bars or out of John Wayne quotes between friends, of last-minute title changes to impress girlfriends named Peggy Sue came thick and fast. Who’s to say it isn’t all as simple and as true as that? Maybe the legends are only a B-side.

item.title: A pub date with Lance, who describes himself as short, fat and bald
item.trailText: He’d bought a bottle of wine and was dressed as if about to go down a ravine with Bear Grylls
item.standFirst: He’d bought a bottle of wine and was dressed as if about to go down a ravine with Bear Grylls
item.body:
Miles’s smiling face popped up on another dating site this week, one he’d freshly joined, and so I sent him a message via their system, just saying hello. He’d said he wanted to be friends. He didn’t, though.

Back came the reply: “I’m sorry again that I disappeared on you. I felt overwhelmed. To be honest, all that stuff about wanting to be stitched into someone else’s life was kind of claustrophobic.”

It wasn’t that, Miles. It was my body – tell the truth, I said aloud to the screen, but didn’t write. So it wasn’t really my not conforming to his type. It was my neediness that damned me.

I asked what was wrong with wanting to be stitched into someone else’s life, if the stitching was mutual and contented. He said that living alone had taught him that he needs to be fundamentally independent. Shared meals, evenings, nights, should be a matter of choice: surely that was a truly liberated way of life? When I argued with this, he interpreted my scepticism as a proposition.

“I can’t offer what you want,” he wrote. “And nice though it is to hear from you, I can’t offer you a date either.”

I wasn’t looking for a date. “I’m not looking for a date, but thanks. Just saw your face pop up here and thought I’d say hello. All the best. Good luck.”

When I logged into another website that I’m registered on, there was a message from him. He’d joined the day before, found me and written to say he thought we should have that lunch at his house and see what happens. But that was before we’d had the conversation we’d just had. “I don’t imagine this invitation still stands,” I replied. He did not answer.

Then, there was an email from Lee, the Austrian, saying that he regretted we hadn’t met, in the end, and that we should have had the conversation about femininity face to face as it might have turned out differently. We would have smiled while we argued. We would have enjoyed the debate. Good relationships need friction, after all, he said. How about a drink? OK, I said. A drink. Why not. When, where? He didn’t reply. I wrote again. “Just name the day. Name the date.” Then I laughed a lot at my own joke.

The culmination of this series of blasts from the past was a dating site message from Peter. It was as if I’d conjured him up by thinking about him, my long-distance disappointment of February. Peter has my email address and mobile number, but opted for the formality of the site email system.

“Hello again. How’s it going for you?” he asked blandly. I told him it was going fine. He launched in to an account of his life since he’d kissed my head and got on a train and dumped me. He’d had a few short-term relationships. He’d thought he’d found “the one”, and then it turned out she wasn’t. They’d got on each other’s nerves. He’d realised that he needed to stop chasing the pretty girls and think about the intellectual fit. “And so – why are you contacting me again, Peter?” I asked him. “Have I been held in reserve until the wind changed?” There was no answer to that.

I put on some lipstick and a red frock and went to the pub to meet Lance. Lance is short and plain and bald; he’d written a funny message admitting to these failings and listing his good points. (One was that he couldn’t make up his mind about Marmite, and thus was an original thinker, which made me smile.)

At the pub, Lance was already ensconced in a corner and had bought a bottle of wine. We drank it. He was dressed as if he was about to go down into a ravine with Bear Grylls. We didn’t have much to talk about. Eventually he looked at his watch for the fourth time and said he had an early start, and should go home.

Outside, he kissed me on the cheek, and said, “Look, I’m not sure, I have to be honest.”

I said that was fine, and off we went in our different directions. That’s what most internet dates are like. That’s what most of mine are like. They are just not very interesting to read about.

Stella Grey is a pseudonym

cards.rawTitle: Casey Stoney on making the World Cup surge stick

item.title: From the World Cup to … where? How to help women’s football keep growing
item.trailText: When Casey Stoney joined Chelsea at the age of 12, the women’s game was a joke. Now the former England captain is a World Cup hero, the team are stars – and the sport is back in the spotlight. This time, can the surge be made to stick?
item.standFirst: When Casey Stoney joined Chelsea at the age of 12, the women’s game was a joke. Now the former England captain is a World Cup hero, the team are stars – and the sport is back in the spotlight. This time, can the surge be made to stick?
item.body:
Moments after Casey Stoney jogged on to the pitch from the substitutes’ bench in England’s win over Canada, the final whistle blew. Stoney was caught in a tiny bubble of peace: one of those moments where time stops and noise silences and all you can hear is your own voice in your head. “I looked around; 55,000 people. We’d just won our first ever quarter-final,” she says, “and I thought, ‘Things are going to change. Things are going to change because of what we’re doing.’”

Related: England’s women big enough to laugh off FA’s ‘partners and mothers’ tweet | Marina Hyde

The team’s historic success – their third-place finish is the highest of any England side since 1966 – won them bronze medals, accolades, record TV audiences, and approving tweets from Gary Lineker. But the real prize – the prize Stoney was quietly contemplating in that “watershed moment” of locked-in amazement – still awaits, valuable and elusive. To complete their triumph, the women must convert their international success to domestic renown, and stretch a few weeks of public excitement into active support.

“Now we need to make it count,” Stoney nods. She is sitting on the grass outside Kensington Palace, where the team has attended a reception with the Duke of Cambridge – another proof of how well they did. There’s a nervous laugh. “No pressure, then.”

Stoney has a down-to-earth, husky way of talking. She refers to the World Cup as “this event of the last three or four weeks”, which is funny because you would imagine the grandeur of the tournament would contrast too strikingly with her early experiences of football to permit that kind of understatement. As a child, Stoney played in boys’ teams – the only girl in her whole league in Morden, south London, where she grew up. At 11, she was crowned player of the year, and then banned – in those days, the Football Association forbade mixed football for older children; Stoney lost a year’s development before joining Chelsea women at the unwomanly age of 12. For years, football was something she paid to play.

Somehow, in the rumpus on the artificial pitch in Vancouver, while Stoney was whisked into a swirl of celebrating team-mates – semi-final here we come – the sense of all she had been through pushed to the fore. In the dressing room afterwards, she spoke to her colleagues: “I thanked them. I said to the girls, ‘Because of what you’re doing, my little girl’s going to grow up with so many opportunities.’” From this platform, how could the sport not progress?

As England’s elder stateswoman – she is 33, and the former captain – Stoney has a keen sense of her ambassadorial responsibilities to the sport. But since she and her partner, Megan Harris, became mothers to twins seven months ago, the personal responsibilities have been driving her on: “I’ve never wanted to do more or better than I do right now,” she says. She knows that if her son, Teddy, loves football, he’ll be fine. But what about Tilly?

“I’ll take this,” she says, lifting the bronze medal from her chest and examining it. “This is amazing. But it’s what my little girl’s going to grow up with that means more to me than anything, because I know it’s not just about my little girl, it’s about every little girl. What we have done might change the perception of teachers. They might now take an after-school club. It might change the perception of a dad who’s now going to take a daughter to the park to play on a Saturday. All those things mean more than this.”

She lets the medal go. “Little boys are going out in the playground now and saying, ‘I want to be a Fara Williams or a Lucy Bronze.’”

Are they? “I hope so,” she says. She has a way of saying “hope” that endows the word with certainty.

The moments of truth for Stoney and her England team-mates will comeon Sunday, when the Women’s Super League (WSL) recommences after its summer break, and on 1 August, when the women’s FA Cup takes place at Wembley. (Wembley! That’s a first for a cup final. See how good things have got?) Around 10,000 tickets have already been sold.

There’s no holiday for the England women. Stoney, who has the sort of work ethic that enables her to list all her Saturday jobs from the age of 14 (Wimpy, McDonald’s, a bookmakers), is available for selection for Arsenal tomorrow. And then, on top of that, there is the larger job that never goes away, of trying to sell the game to the public. In particular, to raise the interest of the World Cup’s 2.5 million peak TV audience from its resting place on the sofa and redirect it to the home ground of its nearest WSL side. How do you do that?

“It’s the million-dollar question,” says Clare Connor , the former England cricketer whose first international call-up came along with a bill for the blazer, and who is now charged with growing the profile of women’s cricket for the ECB. “For a long time we’ve had women’s sports being very successful, but not necessarily converting that on-pitch global success.”

Related: Germany v England: Women's World Cup third-place play-off – as it happened | Alan Smith

Connor lists the targets: to attract a larger audience, to get the players’ stories known, to increase participation, to win media coverage, drive commercial interest. After their Ashes success, the female cricketers caught the attention of Kia, which sponsored them with cash and a car each. No female footballer has yet attracted an independent sponsorship deal. “Endorsements are pretty much nonexistent, if I’m honest,” says Stoney, who does, at least, have an agent.

This is clearly a bugbear. Can’t her agent get her one? “We’ll see!” she says, in a way that suggests she has been seeing for some time. She thinks that, for a quarter of the cost of men’s sponsorship, a company interested in “values” could get a good deal – a female footballer willing to be generous with her time.

This sort of commercial viability depends on name recognition. At Notts County, for instance, they are rubbing their hands at the own goal that sent England out of the World Cup. It was scored by their captain, Laura Bassett. “Unfortunate as it is for her, it’s great for the club. Her name is out there and with her name is Notts County,” says marketing manager Matt Rowland. Even at this peak in Bassett’s value, the club, currently third in the WSL, has just sold her sponsorship (a club rather than a personal deal) for a measly £250 plus VAT.

Since the launch of the WSL in 2011, the majority of women play professionally (though some earn the minimum wage). Stoney, in her first season as a full-time pro, reports the best fitness results she has ever achieved. The central contracts that England players receive are worth £20,000 a year, with a £500 bonus for each call-up. Stoney adds to that the (lesser) amount she receives as a full-time professional at Arsenal.

Things have come a long way since the early 2000s, when Chelsea’s women were so broke they resorted to an illicit bucket collection outside Stamford Bridge, and Birmingham City’s players unpicked the men’s sponsors’ logo from their shirts in order to re-sell the empty space. But even Stoney, for all her certainty and enthusiasm, admits that she sometimes looks at the progress of England’s female rugby union team – currently world champions – and the cricketers, triumphant in the last two Ashes, and thinks, “It’s slow.” At WSL matches, attendance is up 22% on last season, but the average gate is still only 898.

Related: ECB announces plan to launch Women’s Cricket Super League next year

According to the FA, 2.89 million women and girls play football in England. By 2018 it wants to be the second-biggest participation sport in England, behind men’s football, says Russell James, its head of marketing. In fact, the announcement of record numbers has been an FA marketing device since the early 2000s. In 2002, it declared football the most popular participation sport for women. At the time, this sort of growth in the game was a news story that was always overtaking itself. The figures kept rising; I was among those reporting them.

Maybe that is why, when my own daughter wanted to join a club this year, I expected to find one easily. But the parks, in this part of east London at least, are hardly full of bobbing ponytails. Across the first four years of primary school, only six girls attend football club, stuck in a perennial game of three-a-side. We found a “mixed” club in the end, although so far the mix is about 80 to 1.

So what is holding all these girls back? Is it confidence? “Confidence,” affirms Polly Fildes, who runs the FA’s We Can Play programme. “Also parental support.”

According to recent FA research, “just one in five dads want their daughters to play football”. The fathers who weren’t keen cited peer-to-peer pressures, gender stereotyping and “derogatory results of internet searches”. It is hard to avoid the presumption that a lot of this plugs into the old double bind of sexism and prejudice that says girls are rubbish at sport, and if they’re any good, they’re probably gay.

Related: Casey Stoney: ‘My life would be a hell of a lot simpler if I was straight. Being gay isn’t a choice’

“It’s amazing, isn’t it?” says Stoney, who admits that all these thoughts were on her mind when she came out last year. “That’s why it took me 10 years to do it. Because I didn’t want to reaffirm those stereotypes: ‘Oh, she plays football, she’s going to be a lesbian. Well, no. I’m not gay because I play football, and don’t stereotype all my team-mates just because I am. That’s really, really unfair.” She says – and although she doesn’t sound sad, it is the saddest thing to hear – “I didn’t want them to get tarred with the same brush.”

The men in Stoney’s family were always supportive; she played street football with her cousins; her grandad took her to matches because her mum was at work (mornings cleaning people’s houses, afternoons in a bookmaker, evenings in a pub: this must be where the work ethic comes from). “Go and ask my dad what he thinks of my life, when he’s followed me around the world watching me play,” she says. Perhaps this is what England needs: a generation of soccer dads, to transform the game here in the way “soccer moms” did in the US in the run-up to becoming world champions at the inaugural tournament in 1999.

For now, at least, it is tournaments that drive growth, and in between, women’s football must scrap to keep the game alive in the public imagination. The comfort is that each successive event brings a small lift to the baseline of progress. No wonder Stoney thinks “it’s a bit of a disaster that we’re not going to have an Olympics team”. She sounds cross, citing hockey, in which where “the women qualify as England and play as GB and it’s not a problem”. Her voice quickens; she is thinking of Tilly again. “And it’s not just about this generation, it’s about the next generation, and the generation after that.”

For a short time at least, England’s advance at this World Cup provided a brilliant correction. To be able to wake up a seven-year-old girl with a morning kiss and video highlights of another victory by her national side, her gender, was exquisitely normalising. It’s over now, but there is still a perfect riposte to boys at school (“better than the men did”). And those dreams of a future as a famous footballer seem a shade more realistic – about as realistic, anyway, as most boys’ dreams.
